Problem:
Consider a system modeled by the function \\( z(t) = Ce^{i\omega t} \\) which is a complex exponential representing oscillatory behavior with a constant \\( C \\) and angular frequency \\( \omega \). An operator \\( T \\) acts on \\( z(t) \\) as follows: \\( Tz(t) = z(t + h) \\), where \\( h \\) is a time-shift constant.

If the operator \\( T \\) is applied to \\( z(t) = Ce^{i\omega t} \\) at t = 0 and the function evolves naturally without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if the operator \\( T \\) was never applied?
Explanation: The operator \\( T \\) introduces a time shift to the function, which alters the phase of the complex exponential by \\( e^{i\omega h} \\) at each point. This change permanently shifts all subsequent states of the system, leading to a different state at any time T.
